That's wonderful! You're really absorbing the essence of Cartier-Bresson's and Adams' philosophies and applying them to your own photography.

Cartier-Bresson's concept of the "decisive moment" is all about being attuned to the world around you and capturing the perfect confluence of elements in a single frame. It's not just about clicking the shutter at the right moment, but also about being aware of the dynamics of the scene, the light, the composition, and the emotions. By paying attention to the interactions between people and their environment, you're honing your skills in observing and capturing the subtleties of human behavior.

As for Adams, mastering the zone system is a significant accomplishment. The zone system is a powerful tool for understanding the technical aspects of photography, and it's great that you're experimenting with black-and-white photography. Black-and-white photography is an excellent way to distill the essence of an image, and the zone system helps you control the tonal range to create images with depth and nuance.

By combining Cartier-Bresson's emphasis on the decisive moment with Adams' technical expertise, you're developing a strong foundation in photography. You're learning to see the world in a more nuanced way, to anticipate and capture moments that reveal the human experience, and to control the technical aspects of photography to express your vision.

Remember, the key to improving your photography is to keep practicing, experimenting, and pushing yourself outside of your comfort zone. Keep shooting, and don't be afraid to try new things and take risks. The more you shoot, the more you'll develop your eye and your skills.
